results.notes: Mixed wood with oaks, pines and palms. Growing in sandy soil directly beneath oaks. Scent was something chemical/cleaner but with slightly sweet hint. Some floccus flesh adhering to my fingers after handling. Some pale yellow flesh was noted after bisection. KOH on cap seemed light yellow-orange before drying to pale brown.
results.location_name: Sarasota, Florida, USA

results.notes: Mixed woods, oaks and pines. Despite all the surrounding pine-straw these were directly beneath an oak. Scent was indistinct but the taste was mild and pleasant – having a light savory flavor that persisted shortly. I noticed the specimen I carried around developed some light orange brown staining on the bulb. There were 2 small spots on the cap that had a pink/lilac tint that I circled in one picture for clarity; they were more visible in person. KOH negative on cap skin.
results.location_name: Venice, Florida, USA

results.notes: 99% certain it’s the same as obs. 438813. This species seems to pop back up in the summer; I’ve observed fresh flushes in mid-June persisting until early September (a few dried husks remain much longer/virtually year round).
results.location_name: Sarasota, Florida, USA

results.notes: Mixed woods, pines, oaks and palms. Scent was indistinct and the taste was lightly acrid/bitter which did not persist more than a few seconds after spitting it out. One of the more well rooted Russula I’ve found, also more slender and tall than any I’ve found. Some very pale yellow staining in the interior flesh with KOH, no staining noted on the cap.

results.notes:
Registrado por Teodoro Chivatá, en Yopal Casanare, 2021.

Datos de Yopal, registrado en Bosque Seco Tropical (temporada de lluvia). Precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, Precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio. con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%). cuenta con una altura sobre el nivel del mar entre 0 y 1000 m, una pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, como se referencia en DANE. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas. (Bustamante et al., 2017; DANE, 1999; Castro y Sosa, 2017).

Son comunes plantas representativas como Yarumo (Cecropia peltata), Jobo (Spondias mombin), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.

Recomendaciones para tus registros. Las fotografías y descripciones que hagas, te van a permitir identificar el ejemplar:

-Tomar fotografías de las diferentes estructuras del basidioma/ascoma/cuerpo fructifero/carpoforo/seta (por encima, por debajo y de perfil), su estipe, pileo y base, en el caso de retirar el ejemplar sin conocerlo, debes comprometerte a realizar una descripción detallada para aportar a su conocimiento y que no quede en una muestra arrancada, fotografiada y desechada. Además de retirarlo con sustrato para conocer otras características de la base del basidioma.

-Es importante que describas las dimensiones (altura y diametro), forma, consistencia, textura, color y olor. Recuerda que los ejemplares cambian bastante según su estado de desarrollo, así que es ideal familiarizarse con la zona y temporada en la que crecen, para hacer un seguimiento y logres observar la variabilidad fenotípica del basidioma o ascoma (cuerpo fructífero).

-Toma fotos del entorno y agrega datos del ecosistema (humedad, temperatura, altura, tipo de bosque, insectos asociados, etc).

-No olvides que la determinación de macromicetos es compleja y no se realiza únicamente con fotografías, esta tarea (a nivel de género y especie; en la mayoría) implica actividades de descripción morfológica externa e interna, esporada, reacciones químicas, microscopia e incluso herramientas moleculares (ADN/PCR).

Hongos de Colombia (Bogotá, 2019):
https://www.researchgate.net/...

results.notes: I meant to have posted this find months back but just now got around to uploading the photos off the camera. I couldn’t have been more pleased to have found these. Seemed to be an end of season find for the greater St Louis area. Found along the Meramac river. I have a feeling they are a relatively common find in early April to mid May along the rivers and creeks in eastern Missouri. I have yet to find them in Central Missouri though there is ideal habitat along the Missouri river and its tributaries.
results.location_name: St. Louis Co., Missouri, USA

results.notes: Laetiporus found on a log at Houston Arboretum. Light pore surface but orange margin make me think either L. gilbersonii var. pallidus or L. cincinnatus.

results.notes:
A tiny specimen (3.3 cm wide cap and 7.5 cm overall height) was growing in mixed woods of oak and beech. This is my first time finding this species here. Due to the diminutive size I first thought it was some kind of lepiota till I saw the characteristic basal bulb and the mustard-colored volva. This species not only looks similar to the southern Amanita levistriata and the more widely distributed Amanita “sp-57”, but is also their relative. I think chances are this is the same OTU represented by the sequenced obs 323946 and obs 419703. While I am yet to post DNA data & discussion, the ITS sequences derived from these two collections are 100% identical and only 98.5% and 97.6% similar to those of levistriata and “sp-57, respectively. The latter two are genetically distinct taxa — their ITS sequences have very low to non-existent intra-specific variability and the inter-specific variability of 97.4-97.6% (i.e., a well-defined barcoding gap).
Specimen preserved + fresh tissue sampled in SDS buffer.

results.notes:
A NJMA foray collection. A single fruitbody found by an unknown foray participant. The cap was of the most beautiful shade of gray – with a bluish or greenish tinge – that my point-and-shoot camera couldn’t capture. I’ve asked several other people at the foray, and they all confirmed the “slate hue” to the gray color.
Also note the pulverulence in the upper stipe and the slight pinkish hue to the gills. This collection looks similar to A. rooseveltensis, but in my experience at this stage of development that species has a brown-gray cap.
Specimen preserved + fresh tissue in SDS buffer for DNA sequencing (vial #90).
Sequencing Update (21-Nov-23): Since Sanger sequencing from fresh material in SDS buffer gave highly polymorphic (thru-and-thru) reads, this collection was submitted to Steve Russell (SDR) for ONT-nanopore sequencing. The ITS sequence obtained by SDR is a full-length one (one of many haplotypes?); it’s uploaded to this post. The sequence matches 7 GenBank accessions labeled as Amanita sp. ‘KY02’ with 96.3-99.2% similarity. The first voucher of this species ever sequenced, obs 375754 (from Kentucky), is the most similar one (work by RET). The remaining accessions are by SDR, all derived from collections made in Indiana. The two states border each other.
The present collection is the first confirmed one from outside of the KY-IN area. You’re a long way from home, MO462040! :-)

results.notes:
Growing on a well-rotted, decorticated hardwood log with Pluteus cf. seticeps observation 458003, Trechispora regularis observation 457974 and Oliveonia pauxilla observation 462332. The log was located within a stand of Phyllostachys aurea. Hymenium thin and gelatinous, subvinvisible. All structures inamyloid. Monomitic with simple-septate generative hyphae. Cystidia absent. Basidia terminal, clavate and 4-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: (13.9) 14.1 – 18.5 (23.3) × (8.8) 9.2 – 10.9 µm, Q = (1.3) 1.5 – 1.9 (2.5); N = 12, Me = 17.1 × 9.8 µm; Qe = 1.8. Spores smooth, hyaline, thin-walled and prominently apiculate. Repetitive spores not observed. Spore measurements: (5.1) 5.5 – 7 (7.4) × (4) 4.2 – 5.2 (5.5) µm, Q = (1.1) 1.2 – 1.6 (1.7); N = 30, Me = 6.3 × 4.7 µm; Qe = 1.4.

results.notes: This small amanita was found under birch with oak nearby. The yellow cap on several specimens ranged from 7-8cm in diameter with a darker UV remnants toward the center. The stipes ranged from 12-18 cm long with a yellow PV, and a white basal bulb with yellow UV remnants forming a ring above the bulb. The spores were weakly amyloid with a Q value of 1.38-1.56. The odor was not remarkable. I found larger specimens of a very similar mushroom in the same area last year.

Berkeley, Alameda Co., California, USA

results.notes:
Growing on a well-rotted, decorticated hardwood log with Pluteus cf. seticeps observation 458003, Trechispora regularis observation 457974 and Thanatephorus sp. observation 462306. The log was located within a stand of Phyllostachys aurea. Hymenium white and pruinose with arachnoid margins. All structures inamyloid. Monomitic with simple-septate generative hyphae. Cystidia scattered. Cystidia hyaline, smooth, thin-walled and cylindrical to tapered, some with slightly inflated apices. Cystidia measurements: (27.4) 27.43 – 45.6 × 4.2 – 7.3 µm, Q = 5.3 – 7.85 (7.9); N = 5, Me = 39.5 × 5.9 µm; Qe = 6.8. Basidia ellipsoid to clavate, terminal and 4-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: (9) 10.3 – 16.6 (17.9) × (6.5) 6.7 – 7.5 (7.9) µm, Q = (1.3) 1.5 – 2.4 (2.7); N = 22, Me = 13.7 × 7.1 µm; Qe = 1.9. Spores smooth, hyaline, thin-walled, apiculate and cylindrical to slightly sigmoid. Some spores repetitive. Spore measurements: (7.5) 9.2 – 11.5 (12.5) × (2.3) 2.6 – 3.4 (3.8) µm, Q = (2.7) 3 – 4 (4.2); N = 30, Me = 10.2 × 3.1 µm; Qe = 3.4.

results.notes:
Top 4 best vacuum cleaners for busy moms – tested and review

When you become parents, it doesn’t mean everything else stops bothering you. It means you have more things on your plate but limited time to do it. So it would be best to increase efficiency and spend less time on unimportant things to focus on what really matters, in this case, your children. Today, I want to introduce to you a better way to clean the house with the top 4 top rated vacuum cleaners that I found suitable for moms and parents in general.     

1\. Eureka Brushroll Clean with SuctionSeal Bagless Upright Vacuum

The first one on the list is an upright vacuum cleaner that can deal with all kinds of hair in your household: pet hair, mom hair, daughter’s hair… You don’t have to spend time cutting all the wrapped hair on the brush roll because it has a self-cleaning feature. The suction of this vacuum cleaner is very impressive. It can clean both carpet and bare floor efficiently and quickly, so you can get back to your child in no time. In addition, the Eureka Brushroll Clean has a high-efficiency allergen filter that captures more dust and allergens. So the air surrounding your baby is always clean and fresh. Another point I love about this upright vacuum is that it has the autocord feature to save extra time on tidying the cord.

2\. Dyson Cinetic Big Ball Animal

Another upright vacuum that makes it to the list is the famous Dyson Cinetic Big Ball Animal. I bet you all have an impression of this strangely shaped vacuum cleaner. This cleaning machine is one of the Best Rated Vacuum Cleaners that can travel to corners that not every vacuum cleaner can go. The whole vacuum cleaner is like a big HEPA filter that collects allergies and traps them inside tightly. The Dyson Cinetic Big Ball Animal also has impressive suction power that never goes down during a cleaning session.

3\. Electrolux ErgoRapido Lithium Ion Brushroll Clean Xtra

The third vacuum cleaner on the list is a cordless stick vacuum. The Electrolux ErgoRapido Lithium Ion Brushroll Clean Xtra also has a self-cleaning  brush roll, so you just have to focus on cleaning your home. A great thing about this vacuum cleaner is that you can turn it into a handheld vacuum to clean more places. You can even let your children help with the cleaning by using this vacuum because it’s very easy to maneuver. With the 180 Degree EasySteer Maneuverability technology, your children can pretend that the Electrolux ErgoRapido is a car and push it around the house like a game and clean the floor simultaneously. This cordless vacuum cleaner uses Lithium Ion batteries, so charging time is fast and using time is long, guarantee a smooth cleaning process.

4\. Roomba Robot Vacuum

I bet all parents would agree that robot vacuums are the best vacuum cleaners for moms and dads. These cleaning machines require no effort. You just have to give the command on the phone while holding your baby and the Roomba will go out there to vacuum the house for you. It even gets better if you invest in a robot vacuum with the self-empty feature and can be controlled by your voice via the internet. Robot vacuums are the ultimate choice to clean and take care of your children simultaneously.

What do you think about these best vacuum cleaner reviews? I believe they are all good buddies who can help us take care of the house to spend time with our little angels. So pick one vacuum cleaner that you like on the list and let it helps you with your parenthood.

results.notes:
Boletus (Pulchroboletus?) miniato-pallescens. This is a new one for me, and I am as proud as punch to confirm its presence here in SW Pennsylvania. It’s one of those we knew should be there but had not finalized.

I triggered to mini-p in the field because of the overall stature, the greenish tint to the yellow pores (which tend to age toward orange), and the peach-red cap. It could still have been something else, so I took it home for a “tell” that’s unique to this species. Experts who know the species well swear that it turns a bright orange-red when cooked! So I gave it a try, and… behold! It could be a Pulchroboletus “tell” rather than a mini-p feature, but it definitely seems to work.

Miniato-pallescens confirmed, short of a DNA test. I have the voucher if anyone wants to run it through a lab. Hartwood Acres, under oak, 07-27-2021.

results.notes:
Two specimens, A and B.
Oak-dominated woods; hemlock present.
Caps with red centers suggest these represent a taxon other than A. banningiana.
Stipes lacking yellow floccose deposits point away from A. jacksonii.
Gills were pale yellow, which is not well-represented in the photos.
Specimen marked “B” was sampled for sequencing with FunDiS.
Sequence obtained included all of ITS plus a small part of LSU. Multiple BLAST matches with Amanita banningiana at Cover/Ident = 100%/100% strongly support labeling this collection as such. This is a surprise for me, as my concept of A. banningiana is a cap with more muted yellow on the outer areas and a disc that is not as vividly scarlet as what is seen in the two fruit bodies pictured here.
results.location_name: Ricketts Glen State Park, Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
Open woods near a stream overflow bank; mature hemlock and white pine with some hardwoods mixed in.

Spore lengths not exceeding 14 microns. I mounted spores from a print obtained from the mature specimen and looked at quite a few more than are seen in the photos.
